page.title: Technical Analysis
page.subtitle: Challenge your trading knowledge and sharpen your skills with our interactive Technical Analysis Quiz — test your understanding of chart patterns, indicators, and market psychology to become a more confident and informed trader.

quiz.selectHint: Select an option and submit your answer.

tier.excellent: Excellent! Your TA knowledge is sharp.
tier.good: Nice work! Keep practicing to level up.
tier.retry: Good start—review the lessons and try again.

pool.q: What does a Simple Moving Average (SMA) primarily help traders identify?
options: The average price over a set period, smoothing out noise
The exact turning point of the market
pool.correct: The average price over a set period, smoothing out noise
pool.explain: An SMA smooths price data by averaging a set number of periods, helping reveal the underlying trend.

pool.q: Which type of moving average reacts fastest to recent price changes?
pool.correct: EMA
pool.explain: EMA assigns more weight to recent prices, reacting faster than SMA and typically faster than WMA.

pool.q: A typical moving-average crossover 'buy' signal occurs when…
options: A shorter MA crosses above a longer MA
A longer MA crosses above a shorter MA
pool.correct: A shorter MA crosses above a longer MA
pool.explain: Short-over-long crossovers often signal bullish momentum; the reverse can suggest bearishness.

pool.q: A drawback of using moving averages is that they…
options: Lead price action and predict exact tops/bottoms
Lag price action and can whipsaw in ranges
pool.correct: Lag price action and can whipsaw in ranges
pool.explain: MAs are lagging tools and can generate false signals in choppy, non-trending markets.

pool.q: What is the primary purpose of Bollinger Bands?
options: Show volatility and relative high/low levels around a moving average
pool.correct: Show volatility and relative high/low levels around a moving average
pool.explain: Bands expand/contract with volatility and indicate relative price extremes around an MA.

pool.q: When price touches or closes outside the upper Bollinger Band, it often signals…
pool.correct: Momentum/volatility expansion (not always overbought)
pool.explain: Touches outside bands can indicate strong momentum; context and confirmation are essential.

pool.q: A common parameter for Bollinger Bands is:
pool.correct: 20-period MA with ±2 standard deviations
pool.explain: The classic setting is 20 SMA and bands at ±2σ; tweak for your market/timeframe.

pool.q: The Williams Alligator indicator is composed of:
options: Three lines: jaw, teeth, and lips
pool.correct: Three lines: jaw, teeth, and lips
pool.explain: It uses three smoothed averages with shifts: jaw (slow), teeth (medium), lips (fast).

pool.q: When the Alligator’s lines are intertwined (sleeping), it suggests:
options: A strong trend is in progress
pool.correct: A ranging or low-volatility phase
pool.explain: Intertwined lines indicate consolidation; traders often wait for lines to fan out.

pool.q: The Alligator is considered to be 'eating' (trending) when:
options: The three lines spread and align with price movement
The three lines overlap each other tightly
Only price moves while lines stay flat
pool.correct: The three lines spread and align with price movement
pool.explain: Lines fanning out with directional price implies trend development.

pool.q: RSI readings above ~70 commonly indicate:
pool.correct: Overbought conditions (possible pullback risk)
pool.explain: Overbought can persist in strong trends; always seek structure/confirmation.

pool.q: An RSI value near 30 often suggests:
pool.correct: Oversold conditions (possible bounce risk)
pool.explain: Like overbought, oversold can persist; use with price action for entries.

pool.q: A bullish RSI divergence occurs when:
options: Price makes higher highs while RSI makes lower highs
Price makes lower lows while RSI makes higher lows
pool.correct: Price makes lower lows while RSI makes higher lows
pool.explain: Momentum loss into new price lows can hint at a potential reversal upward.

pool.q: Support is best described as:
options: A price level where buying interest may emerge
A price level where selling must occur
A fixed line that never breaks
pool.correct: A price level where buying interest may emerge
pool.explain: Support is an area where demand historically stepped in; it can break.

pool.q: Resistance is best described as:
options: A price level where selling interest may emerge
pool.correct: A price level where selling interest may emerge
pool.explain: Resistance is the opposite of support—supply historically steps in.

pool.q: Which combination improves signal reliability the most?
options: Using one indicator on one timeframe
Multiple uncorrelated signals and confluence (e.g., trend + momentum + structure)
Adding many indicators of the same type
pool.correct: Multiple uncorrelated signals and confluence (e.g., trend + momentum + structure)
pool.explain: Confluence reduces false positives; diversify signal types and confirm across timeframes.

pool.q: In a sideways (range-bound) market, which tends to be more effective?
pool.correct: Oscillators like RSI/Stochastics
pool.explain: Oscillators can time reversals at range extremes; MAs may whipsaw.

pool.q: Which statement about indicators is most accurate?
options: They guarantee profits if tuned correctly
They are tools to inform decisions, not guarantees
They work only on crypto charts
pool.correct: They are tools to inform decisions, not guarantees
pool.explain: No indicator ensures profits; combine with risk management and discipline.

pool.q: Why use multiple timeframes (MTF) in analysis?
options: To align higher-timeframe trend with lower-timeframe entries
pool.correct: To align higher-timeframe trend with lower-timeframe entries
pool.explain: Top-down analysis improves context and entry timing.

pool.q: What is a common mistake when backtesting indicators?
pool.correct: Overfitting parameters to past data
pool.explain: Overfitting rarely generalizes; always validate on unseen data and include costs.
